awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Developing Market-Ready Cloud-Based Software for Mass Spectrometry Data Processing
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to reduce the cost and increase the quality and throughput of mass spectrometry research through the development of advanced analytical software. Biomedical, biotech, agricultural, and chemical companies spend an estimated $15B per year on mass spectrometry because of the commercial value its measurements provide across a broad range of products and services. This value is highly dependent upon the quality of the software needed to render the experimental output into usable information. The successful completion of the proposed research will enable advancements in existing markets through faster, less expensive, and more accurate data processing, leading to novel medical diagnostics, new drugs, and other new products beyond the reach of the current state-of-the-art.  

This SBIR Phase II project will address the most pressing problems in mass spectrometry by developing analytical software that is improved in two ways: 1) it will cut user analysis time in half through readily customizable automation, interactive hypothesis testing, and fast intuitive interfaces, and 2) it will answer more experimental questions through flexible interfaces that allow users to leverage their domain expertise while intuitively exploring their data. These qualities require leveraging the proof-of-concept achieved in Phase I, where a cloud architecture was developed, onto novel interfaces and algorithms to be developed in Phase II. The principle project goals are to develop an application that allows users to more quickly complete both repetitive (through automation) and custom (through intuitive, flexible exploratory tools) analysis in half the time required by present methods. The time savings will result in much lower personnel cost while simultaneously increasing the number and type of experimental questions that can be answered compared to existing software.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project facilitated Prime Labs to conduct research and development of software to enable certain types of chemists to leverage the high-performance computing power of the cloud from any computer through the use of easy-to-use webpage-based tools. The multi-phase project provided support from inception of the project, enumeration and resolution of technical challenges, development and refinement of working prototypes, and culminating in the launch of an available product.

The project resulted in the development of Prometheus, a platform for mass spectrometry chemists to conduct the computer-based analyses required to render the raw data they generate on their instruments into the descriptions of and conclusions about their samples needed by other scientists. Prometheus enables users to conduct ten times as much research in the same quantity of time as other approaches through tools designed to minimize the amount of time they spend on tasks that are predictable or repetitive. Prometheus maximally leverages user time by enabling them to focus on building associations in the data. The interfaces and supporting backend technologies help them quickly find and identify experimentally-relevant portions of data, build on and reuse relevant prior work, and summarize findings in a fully integrated experience that not only allows but facilitates users following the natural back-and-forth flow through tasks. Prometheus provides users the ability to upload, process, report on, archive, and search any quantity of data in the cloud with much greater simplicity, speed, and flexibility than needed in current approaches bounding multiple software products running on varied sets of hardware and requiring multiple personnel and teams to manage.

The product will facilitate much faster throughput by mass spectrometry scientists by alleviating present bottlenecks in their current work, including computational processing time, human time necessary to navigate prior software not purpose-built for their tasks, and rendering obsolete present needs to continually engage IT and other external assets within their companies for new and continuing data storage and data processing hardware for their work.

The project enabled proof-of-concept and IP creation that made it possible for Prime Labs to attract and close additional outside funding that proved essential for the successful launch of the product.

Improved throughput for mass spectrometry yields improvements that benefit society across the many varied applications of mass spectrometry. To consider one application specifically?the role of mass spectrometry in drug development?the product will decrease time to discovery, cost to bring to market, likelihood of success, cost to manufacture, and extent and cost of safety testing, as all of these components are significantly affected by the time, accuracy, and cost of mass spectrometry analysis.


Last Modified: 06/16/2023
Modified by: Robert Smith
